importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the announcement of China's new export controls on rare-earth metals, signaling a strategic move ahead of high-stakes diplomatic discussions.
The effective date of the new export controls on rare-earth metals and associated equipment, marking when restrictions will begin to apply to foreign companies.
The expected date of the Trump-Xi meeting during the APEC summit in South Korea, which serves as a key diplomatic context for China's export restrictions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 2.5-month window between the announcement of the export controls and their effective date, allowing China to signal its leverage ahead of high-level negotiations.

keyTakeAways: China has expanded its export controls on 12 of the 17 rare-earth metals, including five new additions (holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, ytterbium) and maintaining restrictions on seven previously listed metals (samarium, gadolinium, terbium, dysprosium, lutetium, scandium, yttrium).

The restrictions apply to both rare-earth metals and specialized equipment used in refining them, with foreign companies needing special approvals to export products containing at least 0.1% heavy rare-earth metals.
China cites national security and international non-proliferation concerns, pointing to instances where foreign entities have transferred or processed Chinese rare-earth materials for military use.

Rare-earth metals are essential for critical technologies such as electric vehicles, lithium-ion batteries, AI semiconductors, fighter jets (e.g., F-35), submarines (e.g., Virginia-class), and missile systems.
The US is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products, having imported $22.8 million worth in 2023, and sourced 70% of its rare-earth imports from China between 2020 and 2023.

The move is seen as a strategic signal ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting at the APEC summit, illustrating China’s leverage in trade negotiations and its ability to pressure the US through supply chain control.
China acknowledges exemptions for emergency medical needs, disaster relief, and public health emergencies, showing a balance between control and humanitarian considerations.

Analysts from CSIS and the University of Montana describe the action as a ‘pre-meeting choreography’ designed to strengthen China’s negotiating position and expose vulnerabilities in US industrial resilience.

summaryOfNewsArticle: China has announced new export controls on 12 of the 17 rare-earth metals, including five previously uncontrolled ones, and restricted access to specialized refining equipment. The controls, effective from December 1, 2025, are justified on national security grounds due to concerns over foreign entities using Chinese rare-earth materials for military purposes. This move comes just weeks before a high-stakes meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping at the APEC summit in South Korea, where it is seen as a strategic signal to strengthen China’s leverage in trade negotiations. The US, the world’s largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products, faces significant disruptions in its defence and civilian technology industries, including for fighter jets, submarines, and AI-based semiconductors. Analysts interpret the action as a deliberate 'pre-meeting choreography' to highlight China’s dominance in the rare-earth supply chain and to pressure the US during negotiations, while acknowledging humanitarian exemptions for emergencies.
title: China tightens export controls on rare-earth metals: Why this matters
